title: System Design (Junior-Mid)
description: Core system design concepts and tradeoffs

questions.prompt: SD1. What is the main goal of horizontal scaling?

options.text: Increase capacity by adding more machines
Increase CPU frequency on one server

questions.explanation: Horizontal scaling adds more servers to handle increased load and fault tolerance.

questions.prompt: SD2. Vertical scaling means:

options.text: Adding more resources to a single machine
Adding more servers of same size

questions.explanation: Vertical scaling upgrades a single node with more CPU/RAM/storage.

questions.prompt: SD3. Load balancers are used to:
questions.explanation: Load balancers route traffic across instances to improve availability and utilization.

questions.prompt: SD4. Why use caching?
questions.explanation: Caching reduces repeated expensive reads and lowers response latency.

questions.prompt: SD5. A cache-aside pattern means:

options.text: App reads cache first, then DB on miss

questions.explanation: Cache-aside checks cache first and falls back to DB on miss, then populates cache.

questions.prompt: SD6. TTL in caching stands for:
questions.explanation: TTL controls how long a cache entry remains valid before expiration.

questions.prompt: SD7. CAP theorem tradeoff is about:
questions.explanation: CAP describes tradeoffs among consistency, availability, and partition tolerance.

questions.prompt: SD8. Eventual consistency means:

options.text: Replicas may be temporarily stale but converge later
All nodes always return identical latest data

questions.explanation: Eventual consistency allows temporary staleness while replicas converge over time.

questions.prompt: SD9. SQL databases are generally best when:

options.text: You need transactions and relational integrity

questions.explanation: SQL fits strong relational models and transactional integrity needs.

questions.prompt: SD10. NoSQL is often chosen when:

options.text: Flexible schema and large-scale distribution are needed
Strict ACID joins are the only requirement
You need one fixed relational schema forever

questions.explanation: NoSQL is often chosen for flexible schemas and horizontal distribution.

questions.prompt: SD11. Database indexing primarily improves:
questions.explanation: Indexes speed lookups by avoiding full scans on query predicates.

questions.prompt: SD12. A common tradeoff of adding many indexes is:

options.text: Slower writes and more storage use

questions.explanation: Extra indexes improve reads but cost write performance and storage.

questions.prompt: SD13. Sharding is:

options.text: Splitting data across multiple database instances
Replicating full data to every node

questions.explanation: Sharding splits data across nodes to distribute storage and traffic.

questions.prompt: SD14. Replication helps with:
questions.explanation: Replication provides redundancy and can improve read scalability.

questions.prompt: SD15. A single point of failure is:

options.text: A component whose failure brings down the whole system

questions.explanation: A single point of failure can take down the whole system if it fails.

questions.prompt: SD16. Idempotency in APIs means:

options.text: Same request repeated has same effect

questions.explanation: Idempotency allows safe retries without duplicate side effects.

questions.prompt: SD17. Which HTTP method is usually idempotent?
questions.explanation: PUT is designed to be idempotent when targeting the same resource state.

questions.prompt: SD18. Rate limiting is used to:

options.text: Protect services from abuse and overload

questions.explanation: Rate limits protect services from abuse and accidental overload.

questions.prompt: SD19. API pagination helps by:

options.text: Reducing payload size and improving response time

questions.explanation: Pagination limits payload size and improves performance for large result sets.

questions.prompt: SD20. Cursor-based pagination is often preferred when:

options.text: Data changes frequently and stable page traversal is needed
You always need random page number jumps

questions.explanation: Cursor pagination is stable for changing datasets versus offset pagination.

questions.prompt: SD21. Message queues are useful for:

options.text: Asynchronous decoupling of producers and consumers

questions.explanation: Queues decouple producers and consumers and enable asynchronous processing.

questions.prompt: SD22. At-least-once delivery implies:

options.text: Messages may be delivered more than once
Messages may be lost silently always

questions.explanation: At-least-once delivery means duplicates are possible and must be handled.

questions.prompt: SD23. Why are idempotent consumers important with queues?

options.text: To safely handle duplicate message delivery

questions.explanation: Idempotent consumers avoid duplicate side effects when messages retry.

questions.prompt: SD24. Dead-letter queue (DLQ) stores:
questions.explanation: DLQ captures poison messages for later inspection and remediation.

questions.prompt: SD25. Circuit breaker pattern helps:

options.text: Prevent cascading failures to unhealthy dependencies

questions.explanation: Circuit breakers fail fast to prevent cascading failures on unhealthy dependencies.

questions.prompt: SD26. Backpressure is about:
questions.explanation: Backpressure controls producer rate when consumers cannot keep up.

questions.prompt: SD27. Observability usually includes:
questions.explanation: Observability combines logs, metrics, and traces for diagnosis.

questions.prompt: SD28. P95 latency means:

options.text: 95% of requests are faster than this value

questions.explanation: P95 indicates 95% of requests are faster than the reported latency.

questions.prompt: SD29. SLA defines:
questions.explanation: SLA is an external agreement for service commitments and penalties.

questions.prompt: SD30. SLO is:
questions.explanation: SLO is an internal measurable reliability objective supporting SLAs.

questions.prompt: SD31. Error budget represents:
questions.explanation: Error budget is the allowable unreliability before violating SLO targets.

questions.prompt: SD32. Blue-green deployment goal is to:

options.text: Reduce downtime and enable easy rollback

questions.explanation: Blue-green keeps two environments for safer cutover and rollback.

questions.prompt: SD33. Canary deployment means:

options.text: Release to small % of users before full rollout
Release only to internal QA forever

questions.explanation: Canary releases expose small user segments before broad rollout.

questions.prompt: SD34. Strong consistency is most critical for:
questions.explanation: Financial correctness requires strong consistency for critical state.

questions.prompt: SD35. CDN is mainly used to:

options.text: Serve static content closer to users

questions.explanation: CDNs cache static assets near users to reduce latency and origin load.

questions.prompt: SD36. Why partition by key in distributed systems?

options.text: Distribute load and data across nodes

questions.explanation: Partition keys distribute data and queries across cluster nodes.

questions.prompt: SD37. Hot partition problem occurs when:

options.text: Too much traffic maps to same partition key

questions.explanation: Hot partitions occur when skewed keys overload a single partition.

questions.prompt: SD38. Quorum read/write in distributed DBs is used to:
questions.explanation: Quorum reads/writes trade off consistency, latency, and availability.

questions.prompt: SD39. Leader-follower replication typically supports:

options.text: Writes to leader, reads from followers/leader

questions.explanation: Leader-follower centralizes write ordering and replicates to followers.

questions.prompt: SD40. Event sourcing stores:
questions.explanation: Event sourcing stores immutable domain events to reconstruct state.

questions.prompt: SD41. CQRS separates:
questions.explanation: CQRS separates read and write models to optimize each path.

questions.prompt: SD42. Consistent hashing is commonly used for:

options.text: Distributing keys with minimal reshuffling on node changes

questions.explanation: Consistent hashing minimizes key reshuffling when nodes join/leave.

questions.prompt: SD43. Why use retries with exponential backoff?

options.text: Handle transient failures without overwhelming service

questions.explanation: Exponential backoff reduces retry storms and gives dependencies recovery time.

questions.prompt: SD44. What is the thundering herd problem?

options.text: Many clients retry/fetch simultaneously causing spikes

questions.explanation: Thundering herd is a coordinated surge of requests causing downstream overload.

questions.prompt: SD45. Read-through cache means:

options.text: Cache layer fetches from DB on miss automatically
App manually populates cache after DB read

questions.explanation: Read-through lets cache fetch missing data from backing store automatically.

questions.prompt: SD46. Write-through cache means:

options.text: Writes go to cache and backing store synchronously
Writes only to DB; cache ignored

questions.explanation: Write-through updates cache and store together for consistency.

questions.prompt: SD47. Stateless service instance means:

options.text: No user session state kept in local memory between requests

questions.explanation: Stateless services externalize session state for easier horizontal scaling.

title: Software Engineering (Mid-Senior)
description: Architecture, reliability, data, and delivery at scale

questions.prompt: SEMS1. In distributed APIs, why use idempotency keys?
questions.explanation: They allow safe retries by preventing duplicate side effects.

options.text: Prevent duplicate side effects on retries

questions.prompt: SEMS2. Which pattern keeps DB writes and event publish consistent?
questions.explanation: Transactional outbox persists events in the same transaction as state changes.

questions.prompt: SEMS3. What is the primary purpose of a Saga?
questions.explanation: It coordinates distributed steps with compensating actions on failure.

questions.prompt: SEMS4. Which isolation level blocks dirty reads?
questions.explanation: Read Committed and stronger levels prevent reading uncommitted data.

questions.prompt: SEMS5. Main microservices tradeoff versus monolith?
questions.explanation: You gain isolation but pay extra distributed-system and ops complexity.

questions.prompt: SEMS6. What does p99 latency measure?
questions.explanation: 99 percent of requests complete faster than that latency value.

questions.prompt: SEMS7. Why prefer canary releases?
questions.explanation: They reduce blast radius by exposing changes to a small cohort first.

questions.prompt: SEMS8. Which metric best reflects API reliability to users?
questions.explanation: Success rate under valid requests directly represents user outcomes.

questions.prompt: SEMS9. Key advantage of CQRS?
questions.explanation: Read and write models can be optimized independently for workload shape.

options.text: Independent optimization of reads and writes

questions.prompt: SEMS10. Why use distributed tracing?
questions.explanation: Tracing links spans across services to isolate latency and failures.

questions.prompt: SEMS11. Offset pagination risk at large offsets?
questions.explanation: Large offsets scan and discard many rows, hurting performance and stability.

questions.prompt: SEMS12. Best mitigation for cache stampede?
questions.explanation: Request coalescing ensures one recomputation per hot key.

questions.prompt: SEMS13. Dead-letter queue purpose?
questions.explanation: It isolates repeatedly failing messages for analysis and replay.

options.text: Store poison messages for later handling

questions.prompt: SEMS14. Primary goal of rate limiting?
questions.explanation: Rate limits protect service availability and fairness under load.

questions.prompt: SEMS15. Which pattern prevents cascading dependency failures?
questions.explanation: Circuit breakers fail fast during downstream instability.

questions.prompt: SEMS16. Eventual consistency means?
questions.explanation: Replicas may be temporarily stale but converge eventually.

questions.prompt: SEMS17. Best way to reduce blast radius of one failing dependency?
questions.explanation: Bulkheads isolate resources so one dependency cannot starve others.

questions.prompt: SEMS18. Why use feature flags in production?
questions.explanation: They decouple deployment from release and support fast rollback.

questions.prompt: SEMS19. What does RPO define?
questions.explanation: RPO is tolerated data loss window in time during disaster recovery.

questions.prompt: SEMS20. What does RTO define?
questions.explanation: RTO is target duration to restore service operation after outage.

questions.prompt: SEMS21. Why make DB migrations backward compatible first?
questions.explanation: Old and new app versions can run concurrently during rolling deploys.

questions.prompt: SEMS22. Best index for queries by tenant_id and created_at?
questions.explanation: Composite index matching filter/order columns typically performs best.

questions.prompt: SEMS23. Why is N+1 query pattern harmful?
questions.explanation: It multiplies DB round trips and increases tail latency.

questions.prompt: SEMS24. Connection pooling primarily helps by?
questions.explanation: Reusing connections reduces setup overhead and bounds DB concurrency.

questions.prompt: SEMS25. For social-like counters, which consistency is commonly acceptable?
questions.explanation: Eventual consistency is often adequate for non-critical counters.

questions.prompt: SEMS26. Backpressure in stream processing means?
questions.explanation: Consumers signal producers to slow down to avoid buffer exhaustion.

questions.prompt: SEMS27. Main benefit of correlation IDs in logs?
questions.explanation: They connect logs from one request across services and layers.

questions.prompt: SEMS28. Expand-contract migration strategy provides?
questions.explanation: Safe zero-downtime schema evolution across rolling deployments.

questions.prompt: SEMS29. Why store immutable events in event sourcing?
questions.explanation: Immutable history supports replay, auditing, and temporal debugging.

questions.prompt: SEMS30. Risk of synchronous fan-out to many downstream services?
questions.explanation: Tail latency and failure probability increase with each dependency.

questions.prompt: SEMS31. What helps maintain API compatibility long-term?
questions.explanation: Versioning and additive changes reduce client breakage risk.

questions.prompt: SEMS32. Version-column optimistic locking is used to?
questions.explanation: Detect concurrent conflicting writes without long-held locks.

questions.prompt: SEMS33. SLO stands for?
questions.explanation: SLO is Service Level Objective, an internal reliability target.

questions.prompt: SEMS34. Why run controlled chaos experiments?
questions.explanation: To validate resilience assumptions before real incidents occur.

questions.prompt: SEMS35. Practical reason to partition by tenant?
questions.explanation: Improves noisy-neighbor isolation and scaling characteristics.

questions.prompt: SEMS36. Best baseline for external dependency resilience?
questions.explanation: Use bounded timeouts, retries with backoff, and circuit breakers.

questions.prompt: SEMS37. Main purpose of read replicas?
questions.explanation: They offload read traffic from primaries and improve read scalability.

questions.prompt: SEMS38. Why add jitter to retry backoff?
questions.explanation: Jitter avoids synchronized retries that create traffic spikes.

questions.prompt: SEMS39. Which release signal often implies rollback?
questions.explanation: Sharp post-deploy error-rate regressions typically indicate bad rollout.

questions.prompt: SEMS40. Why separate readiness and liveness probes?
questions.explanation: One governs traffic routing readiness, the other restart health.

options.text: Different signals for routing vs restart

questions.prompt: SEMS41. Core benefit of immutable infrastructure?
questions.explanation: Rebuild-and-replace reduces config drift and environment skew.

questions.prompt: SEMS42. Why contract-test service integrations?
questions.explanation: It catches breaking API changes early without full end-to-end runs.

questions.prompt: SEMS43. Write-ahead logs provide what guarantee?
questions.explanation: Durability and recovery after crashes by persisting intents first.

questions.prompt: SEMS44. Better relevance in search systems often needs?
questions.explanation: Inverted indexes plus scoring/ranking, not exact match only.

questions.prompt: SEMS45. In USE metrics, saturation indicates?
questions.explanation: Growing queueing/capacity pressure before hard failure.

questions.prompt: SEMS46. Purpose of bounded contexts in DDD?
questions.explanation: They define explicit model boundaries and reduce ambiguity.

questions.prompt: SEMS47. Common caching anti-pattern for critical data?
questions.explanation: Caching volatile critical state without invalidation causes stale reads.

questions.prompt: SEMS48. Why tune alerts around blast radius?
questions.explanation: Impact-aware alerts prioritize user harm and reduce alert fatigue.

questions.prompt: SEMS49. How to preserve ordering per entity in event streams?
questions.explanation: Partition by entity key so related events go to same ordered shard.

questions.prompt: SEMS50. First priority in senior incident response?
questions.explanation: Stabilize user impact first, then run structured diagnosis.

options.text: Mitigate impact before deep root cause work

questions.prompt: SEMS51. Primary goal of architecture decision records (ADRs)?
questions.explanation: ADRs create durable engineering context for future maintainers.

questions.prompt: SEMS52. Why define service SLOs before tuning alerts?
questions.explanation: SLOs provide objective reliability targets and alert boundaries.

options.text: To align alerts to user impact and error budgets

questions.prompt: SEMS53. What does a good incident timeline provide?
questions.explanation: A clear timeline prevents guesswork during postmortems.

questions.prompt: SEMS54. Best reason to use canary releases?
questions.explanation: Canaries expose new code to a subset of traffic first.

options.text: Limit blast radius while validating production behavior

questions.prompt: SEMS55. What is a common drawback of tightly coupled microservices?
questions.explanation: Excessive coupling reduces independence and increases coordination cost.

questions.prompt: SEMS56. Why use idempotency keys on write APIs?
questions.explanation: Idempotency keys make retried operations safe.

options.text: Prevent duplicate side effects on retries

questions.prompt: SEMS57. When is eventual consistency usually acceptable?
questions.explanation: Eventual consistency trades immediacy for availability and scale.

options.text: When ordering is irrelevant and unknown

questions.prompt: SEMS58. Key benefit of outbox pattern?
questions.explanation: Outbox avoids dual-write inconsistency between DB and broker.

options.text: Reliable event publication with DB state changes

questions.prompt: SEMS59. Most useful first step in debugging production latency spike?
questions.explanation: Start with observability and change correlation before deep fixes.

options.text: Check golden signals and recent changes

questions.prompt: SEMS60. Why keep runbooks near on-call workflows?
questions.explanation: Actionable runbooks improve incident handling under stress.

options.text: Reduce response time and decision ambiguity

questions.prompt: SEMS61. What does p99 latency reflect better than average?
questions.explanation: Tail latency reveals worst-case user impact hidden by averages.

questions.prompt: SEMS62. Why segment metrics by tenant or region?
questions.explanation: Aggregated metrics can hide severe partial outages.

options.text: Detect localized failures hidden in aggregates

questions.prompt: SEMS63. What is the risk of unbounded queues?
questions.explanation: Unbounded buffers hide overload until failure becomes severe.

questions.prompt: SEMS64. What does backpressure achieve?
questions.explanation: Backpressure keeps consumers from being overwhelmed.

options.text: Protects systems by controlling producer rate

questions.prompt: SEMS65. When should you favor synchronous RPC over async messaging?
questions.explanation: RPC fits request-response use cases needing quick answers.

questions.prompt: SEMS66. A practical reason to version external APIs?
questions.explanation: Versioning enables gradual migration and compatibility management.

options.text: Evolve contracts without breaking existing clients

questions.prompt: SEMS67. What makes a deprecation policy effective?
questions.explanation: Predictable deprecation reduces consumer risk.

options.text: Clear timelines, telemetry, and migration guides

questions.prompt: SEMS68. Which database index strategy usually helps read-heavy filters?
questions.explanation: Indexes should be query-driven, not blanket applied.

questions.prompt: SEMS69. Tradeoff of heavy indexing on write-heavy tables?
questions.explanation: Each index must be updated on writes.

questions.prompt: SEMS70. Why use connection pooling?
questions.explanation: Pooling reduces overhead and improves throughput.

questions.prompt: SEMS71. What is a key sign of a noisy alert?
questions.explanation: Noisy alerts drive fatigue and slower true incident response.

questions.prompt: SEMS72. Why run game days or chaos experiments?
questions.explanation: Controlled failure drills expose weak spots proactively.

options.text: Validate resilience assumptions before real incidents

questions.prompt: SEMS73. Best outcome of blameless postmortems?
questions.explanation: Blameless reviews focus on process and system fixes.

questions.prompt: SEMS74. Why standardize structured logging fields?
questions.explanation: Consistent fields make logs machine-usable at scale.

questions.prompt: SEMS75. When does sampling in distributed tracing help?
questions.explanation: Sampling balances observability cost and visibility.

options.text: Control overhead while preserving diagnostic value

questions.prompt: SEMS76. Main purpose of a circuit breaker?
questions.explanation: Circuit breakers prevent repeated costly calls to failing services.

options.text: Fail fast to protect downstream dependencies

questions.prompt: SEMS77. Why combine timeout + retry + jitter?
questions.explanation: These controls together reduce cascading overload.

options.text: Improve resilience without synchronized retry storms

questions.prompt: SEMS78. What is the pitfall of global transactions across services?
questions.explanation: Distributed transactions can be fragile and costly operationally.

questions.prompt: SEMS79. When are sagas commonly used?
questions.explanation: Sagas coordinate local transactions with compensations.

questions.prompt: SEMS80. What is compensation in saga patterns?
questions.explanation: Compensation handles partial failures in distributed processes.

options.text: A corrective action to undo prior step effects

questions.prompt: SEMS81. Why enforce schema compatibility in event streams?
questions.explanation: Schema rules protect independent service deployment.

options.text: Prevent consumer breakages during producer evolution

questions.prompt: SEMS82. What does consumer lag indicate?
questions.explanation: Lag is a key health signal for stream processing.

questions.prompt: SEMS83. Benefit of feature ownership mapping per service?
questions.explanation: Ownership clarity speeds decisions and escalation.

options.text: Faster incident routing and clearer accountability

questions.prompt: SEMS84. Why gate risky changes behind kill switches?
questions.explanation: Kill switches reduce MTTR during bad rollouts.

options.text: Disable problematic behavior quickly without redeploy

questions.prompt: SEMS85. What is a good default for secrets rotation?
questions.explanation: Automation reduces human error and exposure window.

questions.prompt: SEMS86. What does principle of least privilege reduce?
questions.explanation: Tight permissions limit damage from misuse.

questions.prompt: SEMS87. Why track cost alongside performance metrics?
questions.explanation: Engineering choices should balance reliability and spend.

questions.prompt: SEMS88. What is capacity planning primarily about?
questions.explanation: Capacity planning prevents outages and waste.

questions.prompt: SEMS89. Which signal best supports autoscaling decisions?
questions.explanation: Scaling should follow meaningful workload indicators.

options.text: Load metric tied to saturation and latency

questions.prompt: SEMS90. Why isolate noisy neighbors in multi-tenant systems?
questions.explanation: Isolation controls prevent one tenant from degrading others.

questions.prompt: SEMS91. What does bulkhead isolation provide?
questions.explanation: Bulkheads compartmentalize risk and protect critical paths.

options.text: Limits failure impact to a subsystem boundary

questions.prompt: SEMS92. When should you choose blue-green deployment?
questions.explanation: Blue-green enables near-instant traffic cutover and rollback.

options.text: Need fast rollback with full environment switch

questions.prompt: SEMS93. Why collect leading indicators, not only lagging incidents?
questions.explanation: Leading signals support proactive reliability work.

options.text: Detect risk trends before outages occur

questions.prompt: SEMS94. What is the purpose of error budgets?
questions.explanation: Error budgets quantify acceptable unreliability against SLOs.

options.text: Balance reliability investment with feature delivery

questions.prompt: SEMS95. Which practice improves large-team codebase maintainability?
questions.explanation: Strong boundaries and tooling reduce entropy as teams scale.

options.text: Clear boundaries, ownership, and automated quality gates

questions.prompt: SEMS96. Why require reproducible builds?
questions.explanation: Reproducibility helps verify artifact integrity.

options.text: Increase supply-chain trust and debugging reliability

questions.prompt: SEMS97. How should rollback plans be validated?
questions.explanation: Drilled rollback procedures reduce recovery time.

options.text: Practice them regularly in realistic scenarios

questions.prompt: SEMS98. What is a common anti-pattern in architecture evolution?
questions.explanation: Incremental migration lowers risk compared to all-at-once rewrites.

options.text: Big-bang rewrites without incremental migration path

questions.prompt: SEMS99. Why keep contract and load tests in CI/CD quality gates?
questions.explanation: Quality gates prevent expensive production regressions.

options.text: Catch compatibility and capacity regressions early

questions.prompt: SEMS100. Senior engineering leadership in incidents should prioritize?
questions.explanation: Leadership focus should stabilize users and guide effective response.

options.text: Clear communication, mitigation, and coordinated ownership
